subject: Re: Injecting new life into the Quikscript community
msgSnippet: I think you ve conveyed this in a way that is impossible to misunderstand. I am not yours to command, and you have confirmed what I read the first time: No
messageBody:
I think you've conveyed this in a way that is impossible to misunderstand.

I am not yours to command, and you have confirmed what I read the first time:

No activity is better than a wasted activity, eh?

I'll concur.


On Jul 1, 2013, at 7:00 PM, Nathan Sharfi <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:

 

From what I gather, I didn't convey tone in a way that would have been impossible to misunderstand — I was simply puzzled why someone would need our voice samples as opposed to something that's a bit more nationally representative. If you've been following the posts John Cowan and I have been sending back and forth, you'd have noticed that our speech isn't necessarily representative of where we're from/in, so sampling us would've been of limited utility. Plus there're other things that require Quikscript expertise…

If you're looking to inject some life into the community, here're a few things that I'd like to do, but haven't quite had the time/inclination for:

  • Design a largely QWERTY-compatible keyboard layout for Quikscript that disunifies parentheses from angle parentheses, omits half-letters (use OpenType substitution for that), and doesn't throw away any useful other punctuation.
  • Hold a nice, public discussion on what can be safely thrown away on a Quikscript keyboard ought to be useful — King Kong's supported punctuation is a strict superset of what's on a normal US keyboard, but this might not be strictly necessary — and I'm kinda fuzzy on how AltGr is supposed to work on keyboards that have that key, anyway. At any rate, it'd be nice to learn how AltGr works on Windows — I know that while it's conceptually similar to the Option key on the Mac, I don't know if AltGr users have preexisting expectations on what keys should do what. At any rate, there are quite a few keyboard layouts already buried in the Files section of this group, and — speaking as a keyboard-layout creator — get some feedback on what one non-experimental layout I should focus most of my time on.
  • Track down all the authors of all the Quikscript fonts that're out there and get them to clarify their license terms — ideally, with an explicit public domain dedication. The term "freeware" is ambiguous, and I'd rather not allocate my time to playing in someone else's sandbox. As for Kingsley — tracking down "tinyallen" shouldn't be difficult since he's been active on the list over the past couple days, but I don't know about Messrs. Stephen Bartok and Oliver Langan. At any rate, the copyright field says "Typeface copyright High-Logic. 1999, 2002. All Rights Reserved", but the license field says "This is a freeware font.". Since High-Logic is a company that makes font-making software, I'd suspect that it was inserted without the original author's intent — but I'm not sure. At any rate, getting them to publish their font sources — as a UFO, say — would be great.
  • Figure out, collectively, a NATO alphabet for Quikscript (this echoes Tim Rice's call for better names). Ideally, all letters should start with the sound that they're for, not be anything that needs a name dot (i.e. no proper names), and be obvious to everyone what each is even when shouted over a bad cell-phone connection with significant amounts of background noise. This doesn't need to be the work of one person; Google Spreadsheets sounds like the sort of thing that could be used to collaborate on all this. This would help me out personally, because "ah" and "awe" are homophones to my ears, and distinguishing between .Ah/.Awe/.Ox is difficult.
  • Make a nice chart, ideally in HTML using codepoints in the Private Use Area, that shows all the letter combinations one might reasonably make in Quikscript. This is useful for testing kerning and alternate letterforms (does .Utter.Low actually get turned into .UtterAlt.Low?) Don't forget Senior Quikscript abbreviations like .Thaw.Ing for "thing". (Part of) the hard part would be designing a layout that's nice and systematic.
  • Develop a pangram or three that uses every letter in the Quikscript alphabet. The closest I've come was "What is the price of a foot-bath kit? A goose in a dress near North Square thought it would cure jelly ankle. The goat nurse suggested palm oil in the mouth or wrapped around the ankle with a cloth." — which is still missing the following sounds: S, Z, tS, j, h, W. Oh, and it's too effing long to fit in my head. The checker I used I've posted as a gist on GitHub — if there's demand, I could redo the thing in Javascript and put it out there on my website similar to the Shavian converter. Again, none of this needs to be done as solitary work — having some back-and-forth with others, in public, on things like this'd be nice.

You could also start a blog in Quikscript, as I've done. If you're having trouble getting it to work right, don't hesitate to ask on the list. Similarly, if you're having trouble getting Quikscript to work OK in whatever you're doing, ask on the list. Making QS less annoying to use on the computer will help adoption, but I don't know where the usual pain points are, especially for Windows users who aren't computer nerds.

Thank you for helping us help you help us all,
Nathan


On Jul 1, 2013, at 12:23 PM, HeyMister <booth.g@...> wrote:

And now I know why the group is dead. I'm sure I'm not the first person you've helped.

Of course, you are right. It must be documented elsewhere, not that you'd be able to find and post links to such comparative recordings, but no matter.

Better that there is no activity than wasted activity,eh? I'll concur.
